definitions.definition: towards or in a higher position

examples.text: He jumped up from his chair.
Your mum said you were **up here** *(= upstairs)*.
The sun was already up *(= had risen)* when they set off.
They live up in the mountains.
It didn't take long to put the tent up.
You look nice with your hair up *(= arranged on top of or at the back of your head)*.
Lay the cards face up *(= facing upwards)* on the table.
**Up you come!** *(= said when lifting a child)*
The car was up on blocks.
I was up on deck at first light.
Two men were up on the roof, repairing a leak.
I pinned the notice up on the wall.
She tries to stay under water but she floats **back up**.

definitions.definition: to or at a higher level

examples.text: She turned the volume up.
Prices are still going up *(= rising)*.
United were 3–1 up at half-time.
The wind is getting up *(= blowing more strongly)*.
Sales are **well up on** last year.

definitions.definition: to the place where somebody/something is

examples.text: A car drove up and he got in.
She went straight up to the door and knocked loudly.

definitions.definition: out of bed

examples.text: I stayed up late *(= did not go to bed until late)* last night.
He's **up and about** again after his illness.

definitions.definition: to or at an important place, especially a large city

examples.text: We're going up to New York for the day.
His son's up at Oxford *(= Oxford University)*.

definitions.definition: to a place in the north of a country; further north than somewhere else

examples.text: They've moved up north.
We drove up to Inverness to see my father.
I'm **up there** almost every other weekend
**Up here** in Liverpool things are different.

definitions.definition: completely

examples.text: We ate all the food up.
The stream has dried up.

definitions.definition: so as to be finished or closed

examples.text: I have some paperwork to finish up.
Do your coat up; it's cold.

definitions.definition: into pieces or parts

examples.text: She tore the paper up.
They've had the road up *(= with the surface broken or removed)* to lay some pipes.
How shall we divide up the work?

definitions.definition: so as to be formed or brought together

examples.text: The government agreed to set up a committee of inquiry.
She gathered up her belongings.

definitions.definition: finished; over

examples.text: Time's up. Stop writing and hand in your papers.

definitions.definition: used to say that something is happening, especially something unusual or unpleasant

examples.text: I could tell **something was up** by the looks on their faces.
**What's up?** *(= What is the matter?)*
**What's up with** him? He looks furious.
Is anything up? You can tell me.

definitions.definition: about to happen, be discussed, etc.

examples.text: **Next up** in our top ten is a new release by Ariana Grande.
Up after the break we will be introducing our mystery guest!

definitions.definition: to be somebody’s duty or responsibility; to be for somebody to decide

examples.text: It's not up to you to tell me how to do my job.
Shall we eat out or stay in? It's up to you.

definitions.definition: to be of poor quality; to not be very good

examples.text: His work isn't up to much.

definitions.definition: facing problems or opposition

examples.text: Teachers are up against some major problems these days.
She's really **up against it** *(= in a difficult situation)*.

definitions.definition: moving upwards and downwards

examples.text: The boat bobbed up and down on the water.

definitions.definition: in one direction and then in the opposite direction

examples.text: She was pacing up and down in front of her desk.

definitions.definition: sometimes good and sometimes bad

examples.text: My relationship with him was up and down.

definitions.definition: if you swear up and down that something is true, you say that it is definitely true
working; being used

examples.text: By that time the new system should be up and running.

definitions.definition: appearing in front of somebody in authority for a judgement to be made about something that you have done

examples.text: He came up before the local magistrate for speeding.

definitions.definition: on offer for something

examples.text: The house is up for sale.

definitions.definition: being considered for something, especially as a candidate

examples.text: Two candidates are up for election.

definitions.definition: willing to take part in a particular activity

examples.text: We're going clubbing tonight. Are you **up for it**?

definitions.definition: among or almost the best, worst, most important, etc.

examples.text: It may not have been the worst week of my life but it's up there.
OK, it's not my absolute dream, but it's up there.
These people can’t live without the internet—it’s up there with air and water.

definitions.definition: as far as a particular number, level, etc.

examples.text: I can take up to four people *(= but no more than four)* in my car.
The temperature went up to 35°C.

definitions.definition: not further or later than something; until something

examples.text: Read up to page 100.
Up to now he's been very quiet.

definitions.definition: as high or as good as something

examples.text: Her latest book isn't up to her usual standard.

definitions.definition: physically or mentally capable of something

examples.text: He's not up to the job.
I don't feel up to going to work today.

definitions.definition: doing something, especially something bad

examples.text: What's she up to?
What've you been up to?
I'm sure he's **up to no good** *(= doing something bad)*.

wordOrigin: Old English up(p), uppe, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch op and German auf.
